item.title: We're going on a bear hunt..
item.dc:creator: fergustaylor

item.title: Accident Incident Report: 18/06/14
item.dc:creator: fergustaylor
item.content:encoded: Details of incident: After a sunny day kayaking on the Garry - sleepy from an afternoon of BBQ and booty beverages - the kayaking group formally known as GUCC, swam, ferry-glided, or were towed across the river to inspect the rocks beside the final drop. Having surveyed from the rocks, Kayaking President Elderflower reasoned that jumping into the whirling, mass of white water would push the jumper down into the rocky depths for a really long time. Lord President River graded the water as “super gnarly” and “definitely not drowny”, finally adding “who’s in?” Following brief discussion, Kate ‘insert-generic-comment-on-Canada’ Whitaker, reasoned that taking off our BAs would allow the jumper to sink deeper into the murky, airless depths. Some consideration was made as to taking off their helmets for better water-dynamics, but on balance, the group decided that the extra weight of the helmet would allow the swimmer to sink deeper – a compromise in the absence of weighted boots. Shortly before being pulled down river, Cat Mc-[CheapJoke] could be heard shouting “jump in guys, the water’s lovely” also “Argh, save me! Blughhg *glug* *glug* *bubble bubble*” before falling off the rapids below. The rest of the group soon followed to cries of “Whoo!”, “Arhg”, and a hopeful, “I hope someone took pictures!” What caused the event (describe fully): Hubris. What was the consequence of the event (describe fully): Everyone looked especially cool; some sweet videos may be found on the Facebook profiles of the deceased for years to come. Additional Comments: Paramedics on the scene remarked that the jump looked “totally sweet” and “definitely worth a go once we dump these [mottled, water-bloated corpses]”.

item.title: Extreme Survival: A Doctor Explores the Limits of Human Endurance
item.dc:creator: fergustaylor
item.content:encoded:
By Dr Kenneth Kamler
Recounting his experiences with AMS, surviving adrift at sea, as well as performing hand surgery in the not entirely aseptic depths of the Amazonian Rainforest. Dr Kenneth Kamler tells stories of his adventures and those of his friends, to create a gripping depiction of some of the most inhospitable environments in the world and the conditions that can occur in them. He details his reactions to the injuries and uses his skills as a storyteller to examine the actions doctors take in order to treat under pressure. The impact that doctors’ actions can have on a group’s survival is significant, and he raises difficult questions about the right thing to do when a whole team’s lives are at stake. The writer has travelled across the Antarctic, Amazon, and worked on several high altitude projects with the New York Explorers Society, NASA, DARPA, and MIT. From these he selects anecdotes to demonstrate the difficulties of long-expeditions, the limits of human endurance, and the terrible complications that can arise from even routine conditions – far away from specialised medical intervention and supplies. Although Dr Kamler’s notions on human survival seem to stretch the available facts at times; the stories they are based on are fascinating. To anyone with an interest in expedition medicine or the outdoors; this book leaves you with both a sense of wanderlust and adventure. An exceptional read.

item.title: Ethics Case
item.dc:creator: fergustaylor
item.content:encoded:
A) Relevant account of the patient’s context Seen on a medical elective within an Accident and Emergency Department in Kampala, Uganda*. Ms. X*, a 65-year-old woman with long-standing coronary artery disease, had been admitted to the department following a collapse at home. During her admission, she suffered from a new-onset AV block, leading to unstable bradycardia; which was managed with percutaneous, external pacing. In the hospital there were 2 machines capable of electrical defibrillation in an emergency. Both require regular maintenance, and when one fails in an emergency, the other would be substituted. One these machines was being used continuously to pace the patient. The electrical supply to the hospital was also often interrupted multiple times per day, with no back-up generator, and therefore affecting medical equipment. Neither of the 2 machines had an internal power supply, and so would not function during a power outage. The patient’s condition was resistant to chemical intervention, and did not resolve spontaneously following external pacing. She was given procedural sedated for 2 days, continuously paced throughout - awaiting transfer to a distant hospital for a permanent pacemaker. The physician involved said afterwards that;
  1. At the time they thought the patient was going to spontaneously resolve following pacing, freeing up the use of the defibrillator.
  2. They thought the prognosis was poor for the patient, (having not spontaneously resolved, having been paced for so long, being so old, having multi-morbidities), and were unlikely to receive permanent pacing before a terminal complication.
  3. The wait for a transfer to a foreign hospital would be long, and the defibrillator so likely to fail (due to a power failure, or otherwise) in that time, causing the patient’s death.
  4. They thought the pacing procedure caused a lot of harm to the patient.
  5. Overall, they regretted their decision to pace the woman. *Names of the patient and location have been changed. The city/country have been swapped with that of a different country.
B) List the ethical aspects of the case Justice
-A balance of fair distribution of medical resources, competing needs, rights and obligations, and potential conflicts with established legislation - must be considered by the healthcare provider, in order to provide the moral obligation to consider fair adjudication between competing claims. In this scenario, patients may not have access to a defibrillator in an emergency, if they need one. Beneficence The doctors must act in the best interest of Ms. X. At the same time, they must act in the interests of other emergency patients within their care. Non-maleficence -Understand the possibility that withdrawing treatment from Ms. X will likely lead to loss of her life. -Understand that continued external pacing may allow her to access definitive care, leading to a full recovery. -Understand that a long, unpleasant treatment, with a poor prognosis, may not be in her best wishes. Prolonging a poor quality of life for Ms. X with a small chance of later recovery may cause her unnecessary harm and distress to her family. Consent -Understand the principles of consent in an unresponsive patient
  • consider advanced life directives (if present),
  • the doctor’s requirement to make decisions in the patient’s best interests,
  • consider the family/friend’s input as a means to understand the patient’s likely interests (substituted judgement).
 
C) Select the more important ethical aspect and justify this selection In this case there are a number of competing interests towards a limited medical resource. While the patient is being treated at the moment, that care might be withdrawn if it limited the care other patients were likely to receive. Justice, therefore is an appropriate ethical aspect to consider.
In the event of an emergency requiring the defibrillator in use, (deemed likely by staff at the time - as the other was unreliable, and multiple trauma cases were common) the lead physician would have to decide between removing the defibrillator from Ms. X, in effect withdrawing life-sustaining treatment from her, or not providing further life- saving treatment to the second patient, (which may or may not prove successful). Is it appropriate to make a decision in this case? The grounds for withdrawing treatment would be motivated by the interests of a second patient. It would be rationalised at the time by the patient’s prognosis, and likely outcome in the department - compared to the theoretical second patient. But without a second requirement for the machine, this would not otherwise lead to the immediate withdrawal of care (due to the doctor’s perceived ethical division between direct and indirect action, (killing and letting die)). However important ethical considerations of beneficence and maleficence must be made for this patient, making them the most important aspects to consider, due to the reduced chance of her recovery, and increased ability to cause her harm. This is complicated by her inability to consent and assert autonomy.
 
D) Reflective account Ethically, it is the duty of a medical professional to appeal in the best interests of their patient. This is reflected by the ‘duties of a doctor’ registered with the GMC that they, “make the care of your patient [their] first concern,” (Good Medical Practice, GMC 2002:1)
In regards to immediate treatment, (percutaneous pacing), there are legal elements that would apply to support the doctor. Where a patient is not fit to give consent in an emergency, a healthcare provider can act in the UK under the Mental Capacity Act of 2005; in the best interests of the patient - to preserve life, and prevent any deterioration in health. In this case, the doctor would be supported in their initial management of the bradycardia. The patient was never capable of conveying her wishes, being unable to speak during her initial collapse and later sedation. However, if she was she’d be assessed to have capacity based on functional test required by the Mental Capacity Act, Adults with Incapacity (Scotland) Act 2000, or other relevant guideline. The GMC says a doctor, “must assess a patient’s capacity to make a particular decision at the time it needs to be made,” (Consent: Patients and doctors making decisions together, GMC 2002:30). After the immediate threat has passed, as it did on successful pacing being established, it is necessary to consult relatives or friends and those close to the patient. This does not confer their decisions legal validity, but instead helps form the substituted judgement of the doctor; unless they constitute advanced directives under the Mental Capacity Act. Those close to the patient may include carers as well, and under the Adults with Incapacity (Scotland) Act 2000, a proxy decision maker can be appointed. The patient did not recover spontaneously in this case, as the doctor had expected, nor did she deteriorate on pacing, and so the next step of management was identifying a centre that could apply a permanent pacemaker. This was discussed and organised with the family. The patient was externally paced for over 48hrs, and successfully transferred to a foreign hospital for a placement of a permanent pacemaker. During that time, she did not destabilise in her symptoms, and no one required the use of the defibrillator. If they had, the following issues would apply. The doctor is expected to work within a framework of professional regulation; with guidance in the UK being provided by the General Medical Council. Doctors have a clinical responsibility for their decisions. Before a decision is made to withhold or withdraw treatment, they must “carry out a thorough assessment of the patient’s condition and likely prognosis”. (Withholding and withdrawing life-prolonging treatments, GMC 2002:16). The team should also discuss any support the patient may need, as well as those close to the patient. This is supported by the House of Lords (1994), Report of the Select Committee on Medical Ethics, which recommended doctors only take these decisions after appropriate consultation. Following any decisions, these must be well communicated to the team, and that “everyone involved is clear about the arrangements for providing appropriate palliative or terminal care,” (Withholding and withdrawing life-prolonging treatments, GMC 2002:26). Trust between the patient and the doctor (or patient’s family/friends/carers and doctor), is important in order to facilitate care. Any decisions likely to be made that cause distress to the patient and family, should be well explained in advance wherever possible.
 
Ethically, the distinction between withdrawing treatment and never having made it (held by the doctor), is not supported by the current consensus. Although this may cause more distress for the doctor as a direct act, “There is no ethical or legal obligation [in the UK] to continue to provide a treatment where it has been decided that the treatment is not in the best interests of the patient,” (Withholding and withdrawing life-prolonging treatments, GMC 2002:44). As such a decision could be made to withdraw pacing from Ms. X. The decisions, if made, should be properly documented, as well as any discussions with the patient, team, or other individuals involved in deciding. “You should ensure the records are appropriately accessible to the patient, team members and others involved in providing care to the patient.” Finally, “these decisions should be reviewed at appropriate intervals during the agreed treatment”, (Withholding and withdrawing life-prolonging treatments, GMC 2002:27). In this case, any decision to withhold further CPR in case of a deterioration of symptoms would follow the same process. However, in the UK it might be appropriate to make a DNAR order. Guidance from the GMC supports advanced decision making in this case, which should ideally include the “patient’s own views”, or without capacity, “those closest to the patient,” (Withholding and withdrawing life-prolonging treatments, GMC 2002:36).
  E) What should be done?
An attempt should be made by the doctor to identify any family members/friends and make clear the severity of Ms. X’s situation; -The low chance of surviving a long-period of transcutaneous pacing. -The high likelihood of a long transfer wait. -The risk of equipment being compromised by power supply interruptions. They should identify any advanced directives made by Ms. X, and ask about the family member's’/friend’s understanding of Ms. X’s wishes with which to build a substituted judgement on. The doctor should then explain the preferred treatment options, including the possible withdrawal of treatment if necessary, that would be made in the department for Ms. X in consideration of her perceived wishes, and in absence of her ability to consent personally. If continuing treatment, the doctor should try to explain and facilitate any other healthcare options that might be made in the best interest of the patient; such as a transfer to another hospital or department with more pacing devices. The doctor should also attempt to follow local procedure to acquire more emergency equipment. An attempt should also be made to direct any cases requiring defibrillators elsewhere, if there is a reasonable alternative.
  Difference that the case will make to student’s practice
I understand that if I’m aware a patient is not receiving basic care, then I have a responsibility to make this known to someone in a position to act straight away. This is something I have understood in principle before now, however the guidance given for the process of doing so is useful. “25 You must take prompt action if you think that patient safety, dignity or comfort is or may be seriously compromised.” I understand that if I’m aware of patient at risk because of inadequate equipment, such as a faulty defibrillator, I have a responsibility to try to put the matter right if possible. Having looking at the guidance itself has provided a good opportunity to understand the processes and support I should use to do so though. I would not have known this previously. An awareness of this guidance will allow me to act with more confidence and immediacy in future, as well as provide a better response to my colleagues, if they seek advice. The case of the defibrillator is difficult, as an A and E doctor may not be responsible for the provision of equipment. In this department, scarcity may affect other resources more severely. As such the provision of another machine may be a low-priority compared to other resources; nonetheless, this equipment may put a patient at risk. (Both for its unreliable nature, and scarcity). I should try to manage this following the same process, and use a step-up approach to address the problem. “25 a If a patient is not receiving basic care to meet their needs, you must immediately tell someone who is in a position to act straight away.” b If patients are at risk because of inadequate premises, equipment* or other resources, policies or systems, you should put the matter right if that is possible. You must raise your concern in line with our guidance and your workplace policy. You should also make a record of the steps you have taken.” The guidance provides good detail to help me in doing this, in particular the GMC’s “Raising and Action on Concerns in Patient Safety, 2012”. If not able to solve the matter myself, I would try to contact my manager, or appropriate reporting officer for help, (first telling my Consultant, Clinical or Medical Director). Later, if not satisfied with the response, I’d consider raising my concerns with my regulator (the GMC). Finally, having sought help and advice from senior staff/colleagues/ medical defence body/ professional association (e.g BMA) and still not being satisfied with all steps between, I’d consider making it a public concern. But in doing so I’d have to take steps to maintain patient confidentiality. The professional bodies in Uganda* would be different to the UK, however the process remains the same. In consideration of the prognosis of this patient, and to maintain an effective relationship with the public (in this case her relatives), I’ve learnt that I’ll have to maintain good communication, even, (or rather, especially) regarding bad news. If things are likely to go wrong, as they may in this case, it’s important that the family would be made aware of this, so they could understand the severity of the case, and prepare themselves. Otherwise, an unexpected complication could cause even more distress to them, and break down the trust necessary in our relationship. “55 You must be open and honest with patients if things go wrong. If a patient under your care has suffered harm or distress, you should: a put matters right (if that is possible) b offer an apology c explain fully and promptly what has happened and the likely short-term and long-term effects. “

item.title: Junior Elective Report
item.dc:creator: fergustaylor
item.content:encoded:
My elective was a 3 week placement in the Emergency department of Centre Hospitalier Universitaire, Kigali. Followed by a week shadowing the anaesthetic department.
The hospital was the largest in Rwanda, one of two teaching hospitals partnered with the University. The hospital could be described as resource-poor, medical training is not at a similar standard as the UK, and medicine is provided on the basis of private insurance with some social support. The departments are also staffed with American consultants, (brought in under a peer-training program with Rwanda), and who provide the majority of the teaching.
French would be very helpful as a second-language, but enough patients/staff speak English as not to be a problem. Educational supervision (as organised through the University of Rwanda) was poor, but teaching through the staff was frequent and excellent.
In the emergency department of Kigali, capital city of Rwanda, I attended twice-daily ward rounds, evening shifts, local teaching seminars as well as a week in anaesthetics. In my own time, I was able to meet a number of interesting people within healthcare; being invited to Paul Farmer’s house was a highlight, but also talking to anthropologists, nurses, visiting professors and educational staff at the University - all expanded my notions of healthcare in some way. The role doctors and healthcare staff had in the country was extraordinary - not just as a general feature of global health, but as an integral part of governmental developmental policy. During my last week I met the only anaesthetist left in the country after 1994, and was told about the way the country rebuilt their specialities, first sending young doctors to be trained in Europe, later, building peer-training ties that took practitioners worldwide to train doctors in-country.
I was encouraged in my clinical examinations, history taking and clinical skills; but also to actually apply them to complex situations. For example, working with a translator, and examining uncooperative younger patients.
This presented challenges, trying to take a history with a yes/no question could elicit 2 minutes of back-and-forth between the nurse and patient, only to be later answered with a blank-faced “no”. Was important information being given but ignored in summary to me, I wondered? I learned to follow-up my questions to the translator, and eventually we settled on a greater depth of summary. I found this helpful, when I couldn’t otherwise hear the person sounding hesitant, or angry, or even scared - with the subtlety of their cadence lost on me.
The department’s doctors were Rwandan registrars, with US consultants brought in on a peer-support program. They helped me to understand the priorities of healthcare, and how it’s structured around the limitations and challenges of a resource-poor country. The consultants worked for international medical organisations world-wide, (a great insight for me into medical voluntary organisations), and the departments pooled expertise to prioritise the most helpful interventions. Training the doctors to interpret ultrasound well for example, (and understand its limitations) was a quick and easy alternative to unavailable forms of imaging.
After trauma cases came in, I often left the department late, tired and sometimes quite upset. I wouldn’t eat or drink much over the day and realised just how much my mood was being affected. After a while, I started talking to the other students about it, and found just how helpful it was to talk.
I saw a lot of the things that scared me, especially when I was being asked to help the team. Around severe trauma I felt myself become anxious, and it affected my interactions with staff. With practise, I learned to relax, and disconnect myself from reactions - focussing instead about what was happening around me, and trying to anticipate what I should be doing next. Towards the end of my elective, I was surprised to feel far more comfortable in a crisis.
I was surprised many times - when I discovered there was no running water, ‘disposable’ equipment was washed out with soap and water, or when I was told the friendly men doing odd jobs in jumpsuits were prisoners; being reintegrated into the community after crimes relating to the genocide. My elective was an incredibly useful opportunity for me to experience excellent teaching in an environment, and culture I’d never otherwise be able to experience. It’s made me feel far more confident in the limits of my abilities and competence as a student.
http://www.hrhconsortium.moh.gov.rw/
https://hms.harvard.edu/news/hms-partners-rwanda-ministry-health-11-20-12

item.title: "We're going on a bear hunt.."
item.dc:creator: fergustaylor
item.content:encoded:
This was a piece commissioned by the Glasgow Guardian, regarding current negotiations around the second Junior Doctors’ strike. It followed two opinion pieces by other writers earlier that week; putting their arguments both for and against industrial action. As a student representative (gusrc), and medical student, I was invited to “consider [writing on the issue] in order to balance this important debate.” Given the breadth of coverage I felt this had recieved from the previous writers, as well as elsewhere – I pitched a slightly lesser-covered piece of news from earlier that week, that (with the permission of Michael Rosen), I felt helped frame the issue..
Published Article

item.title: A call for Trustees.
item.dc:creator: fergustaylor
item.content:encoded: Since my second year at medical school I've been involved in the formation and running of a charity. Having been preparing to step down in my role as Chair, it fell to me to reach out to new potential trustees within the University-wide newsletter. The writing in context.

item.title: Glasgow ARM - Supporting Rwandan Healthcare Students
item.dc:creator: fergustaylor
item.content:encoded: Last year produced several milestones in the development of Glasgow ARM, and with financial charitable recognition came a huge push forward to increase donations. In order to both thank the Undergraduate Medical School, and highlight the opportunities for further engagement, I wrote the following piece for the 2016 Summer Newsletter. The article in context.

item.title: 'You alright?'
item.dc:creator: fergustaylor
item.content:encoded: Back in my third year of University I was asked to get involved with the Student Union as an opportunity to improve welfare at the Medical School, in particular - Mental Health. I had some successes, including the introduction of a new peer support programme. But the issue of advertising the available services so that students were aware of their options when they needed them - has been poorly approached for some time. On a whim, I wrote the following posters one evening. With a little work. I made the following endorsed by the med school.

item.title: WorldChangers
item.dc:creator: fergustaylor
item.content:encoded: UofGWorldChangers

item.title: Cambodian Adventures
item.dc:creator: fergustaylor

item.title: Senior Elective Report
item.dc:creator: fergustaylor
item.content:encoded:
As a student keen to combine my interests in surgery with the broader, international focus of global health - my elective was an invaluable opportunity. This clinic helped me to understand the ways in which access to affordable, surgical care is being addressed internationally, in particular through the work of NGOs. The ‘neglected stepchild of global health’,* surgery is an important aspect of comprehensive global healthcare. A recent Lancet report estimated surgical conditions account for approximately 30% of the global burden of disease**. However 5 billion people worldwide can’t access safe, affordable surgical and anaesthetics care. During my elective, I saw patients who (without the free clinic) weren’t able to access healthcare services on demand, and who’d waited without surgical care for years. This elective gave me the opportunity to talk to surgeons who’d been working for international charities and healthcare bodies to reverse this inequality for decades.

Some patients I saw had been to public hospitals, but weren’t able to pay for the full care they required. For example, patients had attended elsewhere with closed fractures, they weren’t appropriately reduced at the time of injury, and required subsequent elective, open reduction and fixation in this clinic.

I saw total hip replacements being performed, which not only transformed the patient’s life, but their whole family’s, who would otherwise care for them.

I also saw one-off treatments that were life-changing, but came far later than they should; a sebaceous cyst equal to the size of the patients’ head, for example. Dramatic as the impact that removal had, it followed years of insufficient primary care access - the effects of which are extensive and ongoing.

The impact of untreated surgical conditions is huge, and it was regularly conveyed to me in clinic and in consultations that this posed a significant financial risk to the individual. It scales up through society creating a huge economic impact on the country, and across the world it entrenches poverty.

The clinic and its staff helped me to understand some of the barriers to patients seeking treatment; fear about the pain and complications involved in procedures, fear of the standards of care, and fear of the cost to the individual - all deterred patients from seeking treatment. It required a lot of trust to be built up to redress such apprehension, and not wholly without good reason, I frequently saw surgery performed following earlier medical care. Inappropriate IM injections in the very young meant the clinic treated a number of children with quadriceps fibrosis, requiring surgical release. Untreated, this would be a life-long deformity, impacting their development and affecting the course of the rest of their lives.

Helping families to entrust their children subsequently was a difficult problem for the clinic, as was interacting with the public hospitals responsible.

Whilst I was impressed by the work of this clinic, its work also presented moral dilemmas; it relied upon advertising as a charity. In order to receive free treatment, patients had to agree to the use of their image and personal details in promotional materials. For example, sites such as watsi.org allow clinics to crowd-fund the cost of procedures. The clinic regularly uses patients’ images in their own media (Facebook, website, twitter, blogs and newsletters), as well as for other charities supporting the clinic. In addition, patients must agree to their notes potentially being used in research as well. This was all covered in a document, alongside surgical complications.

This ethical dilemma presented around this is complex; alternative care wasn’t available and the clinic required support to fund treatment. However, this was a huge impact on their doctor-patient confidentiality, a condition we would expect to receive in the UK. To what extent is that principle culturally-based, or universally practical? Ideological or pragmatic?

In summary, this was an educational unit with dramatically different surgical presentations to the UK, providing context to a complex healthcare provision/requirement dynamic, and a technically very interesting reconstructive surgical unit.

*Paul Farmer’s words, not mine.

**http://www.lancetglobalsurgery.org/
